48 class DLLEXPORT Signal final
49 {
50 public:
51  NONCOPYABLE( Signal );
52  DEFINE_PTRS( Signal );
53 
54  Signal();
55  ~Signal();
56 
57  bool HasValue() const;
58 
59  template <class ValueType>
60  ValueType* GetValue();
61 
62  template <class ValueType>
63  void SetValue( ValueType const& newValue );
64 
65  bool CopySignal( Signal::SPtr const& fromSignal );
66  bool MoveSignal( Signal::SPtr const& fromSignal );
67 
68  void ClearValue();
69 
70  std::type_info const& GetType() const;
71 
72 private:
73  struct _ValueHolder
74  {
75  NONCOPYABLE( _ValueHolder );
76 
77  _ValueHolder() = default;
78  virtual ~_ValueHolder() = default;
79 
80  virtual std::type_info const& GetType() const = 0;
81  virtual _ValueHolder* GetCopy() const = 0;
82  virtual void SetValue( _ValueHolder* valueHolder ) = 0;
83  };
84 
85  template <class ValueType>
86  struct _Value final : _ValueHolder
87  {
88  NONCOPYABLE( _Value );
89 
90  _Value( ValueType const& value )
91  : value( value )
92  , type( typeid( ValueType ) )
93  {
94  }
95 
96  virtual std::type_info const& GetType() const override
97  {
98  return type;
99  }
100 
101  virtual _ValueHolder* GetCopy() const override
102  {
103  return new _Value( value );
104  }
105 
106  virtual void SetValue( _ValueHolder* valueHolder ) override
107  {
108  value = ( (_Value<ValueType>*)valueHolder )->value;
109  }
110 
111  ValueType value;
112  std::type_info const& type;
113  };
114 
115  _ValueHolder* _valueHolder = nullptr;
116  bool _hasValue = false;
117 };
118 
119 template <class ValueType>
120 ValueType* Signal::GetValue()
121 {
122  // You might be thinking: Why the raw pointer return here?
123 
124  // This is mainly for performance, and partly for readability. Performance, because returning a
125  // shared_ptr here means having to store the value as a shared_ptr in Signal::_Value too. This
126  // adds yet another level of indirection to the value, as well as some reference counting
127  // overhead. These Get() and Set() methods are VERY frequently called, so doing as little as
128  // possible with the data here is best, which actually aids in the readably of the code too.
129 
130  if ( _hasValue && GetType() == typeid( ValueType ) )
131  {
132  return &( (_Value<ValueType>*)_valueHolder )->value;
133  }
134  else
135  {
136  return nullptr;
137  }
138 }
139 
140 template <class ValueType>
141 void Signal::SetValue( ValueType const& newValue )
142 {
143  if ( GetType() == typeid( ValueType ) )
144  {
145  ( (_Value<ValueType>*)_valueHolder )->value = newValue;
146  }
147  else
148  {
149  delete _valueHolder;
150  _valueHolder = new _Value<ValueType>( newValue );
151  }
152  _hasValue = true;
153 }
